item.title: Ticket #388 (Saving an entry in Firefox takes a long time (minutes) to get to the ...) updated
item.dc:creator: anonymousbugger
item.description:
If this is WP 1.3, this was probably caused by checking the post for enclosures. I have just submitted a patch to speed this up significantly. In wp-includes/functions.php change line 819 from:

while ( !feof($fp) )

TO

while ( !feof($fp) && strpos( $response, "\r\n\r\n" ) == false )

This will make it close the connection when it sees a blank line from the remote server.

item.title: Changeset [1820]: Make checking enclosure URLs much faster - fclose() after blank line ...
item.dc:creator: donncha
item.description: Make checking enclosure URLs much faster - fclose() after blank line in response.

item.title: Ticket #389 (REQUEST_URI is set but null on IIS affecting PATH_INFO permalinks) created

item.description: The existing code in wp-settings.php that corrects for IIS not setting REQUEST_URI does not account for the case where it is set but null. This appears in 1.2 and CVS. See the attached diff for a proposed fix.

item.title: Ticket #387 (Problems with cookies about WordPress/Blog URI) updated
item.dc:creator: anonymousbugger

item.title: Ticket #387 (Problems with cookies about WordPress/Blog URI) created
item.dc:creator: anonymousbugger
item.description:
This is only affecting WP >= 1.2.1

There are basically two problems, that are related:

  1. The Blog URI will mysteriously change, to omit the "www." portion (and maybe other stuff, it's yet to be seen).
  2. If the Blog/WordPress URI is "​http://www.something.com", then cookies for "​http://something.com" will not work.

This is being discussed in this thread: ​http://wordpress.org/support/3/14987

It was said in the thread that it only affects Firefox, but I haven't tried any other browsers myself.

item.title: Ticket #383 (WordPress should check whether PHP MySQL extension is installed) updated
item.dc:creator: tor
item.description:
is_callabale which only checks the specific mysql function, and has an outside chance of getting duped (if mysql wasn't installed but a user-defined function was...) should probably be switched with...

if(!extension_loaded('mysql'))

This would be quite useful since php5 doesn't load the required mysql module anymore by default since they want people to use mysqli.

item.title: Ticket #219 (RSS Summary strips links from description.) updated
item.dc:creator: tor
item.description:
I added a patch that implements this against the newest CVS. RSS 0.92 didn't seem to like a rich xhtml block (wrapped in CDATA) in the description from the docs I read, nor did atom. I'm no expert on this though, so I figured leaving them alone was best policy.

A simple call to the function get_content_truncated should do the trick though, if it's determined something like this is kosher.
